message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive heterophile agglutination test suggests infectious mononucleosis, which increases the risk of Hodgkin lymphoma. Rheumatic fever is a complication of streptococcal pharyngitis. Kaposi sarcoma is seen in immunocompromised individuals. Mycotic aneurysm is not related to infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, positive heterophile agglutination test, and atypical lymphocytes suggest infectious mononucleosis. It is associated with an increased risk of developing Hodgkin lymphoma. None of the other options are associated with infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive heterophile agglutination test and atypical lymphocytes suggest infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus. Although there are no immediate complications, patients with previous Epstein-Barr virus infection are at an increased risk for Hodgkin lymphoma later in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and positive heterophile agglutination test suggest infectious mononucleosis. Chronic infectious mononucleosis is associated with an increased risk for Hodgkin lymphoma, but not the other options listed.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms and positive heterophile agglutination test suggest infectious mononucleosis, which is caused by Epstein-Barr virus. Patients with infectious mononucleosis have an increased risk of developing Hodgkin lymphoma. None of the other options are associated with infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms and positive heterophile agglutination test indicate infectious mononucleosis, which can increase the risk of developing Hodgkin lymphoma later in life. The other options are not associated with infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive heterophile agglutination test and symptoms suggest infectious mononucleosis. Patients with infectious mononucleosis have an increased risk of developing Hodgkin lymphoma later in life. The other options are not associated with infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive heterophile agglutination test suggests infectious mononucleosis, which is associated with an increased risk of Hodgkin lymphoma. The other options are not associated with infectious mononucleosis.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive heterophile agglutination test indicates infectious mononucleosis caused by Epstein-Barr virus. While the patient is not at increased risk for any of the options listed, infectious mononucleosis itself can increase the risk of developing Hodgkin lymphoma later in life.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The positive heterophile agglutination test suggests infectious mononucleosis, which is associated with an increased risk of Hodgkin lymphoma. Rheumatic fever is associated with Group A Streptococcal infection, Kaposi sarcoma is associated with HHV-8 infection, and mycotic aneurysm is associated with bacterial infection.
